reviewText: Based on a true story this movie gives us an excellent view on what children must go through when their parents are involved in a radical movement against their regime. At home with his parents and close relatives he is Juan; at school and elsewhere he is Ernesto. As seen through his eyes we are able to see the conflicts in his life; how he would like to lead a normal life, making friends and inviting them over and all that. But because of the secrecy needed to protect his parents he is restricted from all the things a boy his age would do. There were some tense moments in the film—how his classmates wished him a happy birthday on the day his parents selected for it and he forgot and then inviting them over to his house that weekend for a “birthday” party. He made a friend with a Maria but then again he had to be extremely cautious, making sure there was no “slip of the tongue.” There were times, however, with Maria he wanted to blurt out his life story but the love of his family prevented that from happening. Accolades to the nth degree should go to Teo Gutierrez Moreno for doing an extremely great and superb job in portraying the boy.

reviewText: While the wars that are fought in the presence of journalists grab the headlines, even when they are civil wars, there are others that are almost ignored by western media yet are just as deadly as those where the bombs are exploding. Some of these low intensity civil wars were fought with the connivance of the American government under the excuse of anti-communism. These wars have been referred to as dirty wars and often involved terrorist type actions by a government against their own people.One of the least reported was the dirty war that took place in Argentina in the late seventies and early eighties. No one knows for sure how many people were killed, estimates range from 10,000 to 30,000. The people that the Argentine military disposed of were called "disappeared" for the majority simply vanished without a trace. There were organized groups that fought in opposition to the Argentine military, but those that carried arms were a small minority and the military cast a wide net against all perceived political opponents.This movie is about a cell of the Montoneros guerilla group that was being ruthlessly tracked down by the Argentine military while they fought back using small arms. Juan is a 12-year-old Argentinean boy that has lived in exile with his family for several years. His parents are commanders of a local cell and have made the decision to return to Argentina in secret in order to better carry out the struggle. Juan and his baby sister go with their parents and in order to remain hidden, Juan is now Ernesto.Ernesto goes to school and after a slow start he begins to make friends, especially with the young beauty Maria. Older than his years and desperate to have a normal life, Ernesto tries to win Maria with acts of kindness along with statements that hint at deep secrets. While his parents are serious revolutionaries, his uncle Beto is wild and fun-loving while also remaining dedicated to their cause. It is through Beto that Ernesto is able to stay a child in the grown-up world where the hunters could arrive at any time.This is a movie that describes the brutal events where governments engaged in acts of terror, supposedly in a fight to defeat terrorists. Juan is a boy that becomes Ernesto in order to survive, all he wants is to have a normal life, yet there is simply no way that this will happen. He is able to develop a love generally reserved for older people, yet cannot escape the fact that he is only 12 years old.A movie that pulls the scab off of what often passed as positive anti-communist action, it should be viewed by classes studying the Cold War as it reveals some of what was done in the name of "freedom." Even during the times of childhood joy, there is the undercurrent of a society fighting a war against itself where the government ruthlessly oppressed the people it was supposed to serve. Understanding it requires some knowledge of history, yet even if you don't know of the dirty war and the disappeared, you will be kept on the edge of your seat waiting for the climactic battle. At the end all you can do is hope that Juan can just be Juan.
summary: Some sunlight is shed on the "dirty war" in Argentina, it is not a pleasant sight

reviewText: For so many of us the governmental complexities that seem to occur with regularity in South America never seem to be clear. CLANDESTINE CHILDHOOD (`Infancia clandestine') offers the opportunity to not only be informed about the machinations of such movements, but also allows us entry into the personal view of the changes that political events impact so powerfully  on the citizens.Benjamín Ávila who wrote (with Marcelo Müller) and directed this brilliant little film is sharing his experiences of living through the times that his story relates. The year is 1979 and an Argentinean family who have been exiled in Cuba return to Argentina as Montoneros - a guerilla group fighting against the military junta that controlled Argentina from 1976 to 1983. In a coup on March 24, 1976, a military junta seized power in Argentina and went on a campaign to wipe out left-wing terrorism with terror far worse than the one they were combating. Between 1976 and 1983 - under military rule - thousands of people, most of them dissidents and innocent civilians unconnected with terrorism, were arrested and then  - los desaparecidos. The father Horacio (César Troncoso) and mother Cristina (the incredibly beautiful Uruguayan actress Natalia Oreiro), baby girl Vicki, and 12 year old son Juan are forced to change their names and hide from the authorities so that the guerilla warfare can be accomplished.  There is one  other member of the family - Uncle Beto (Ernesto Alterio) - who seems to be the most solid tie between Juan (now called `Ernesto') and his family's condition.`Ernesto' enters school, discovers Maria (Violeta Palukas) and from there the story becomes more one of a blossoming love than a country under military control. But the fear and eventual capture of Ernesto's family brings an end to a precious little love story: Ernesto must leave with the remaining members of his family and go to live with his grandmother Amalia (Cristina Banegas). Juan/Ernesto's childhood has become a clandestine one.The film is well acted and directed but most important it offers us a view of the conditions of living in Argentina during that dark cloud of Los Desaparecidos. It is a powerful yet very tender document about the effect of war on us all - but especially on children. Grady Harp, April 13
summary: The Struggle to Exist Through the Eyes of a Child

reviewText: The Argentinean drama "Clandestine Childhood" is clearly a very personal film to its writer/director Benjamin Avila. Set in the late seventies, Argentina was under a strict military dictatorship and this created one of the most harrowing times in the country's history. The brutality of the junta is well documented, as are the efforts of those who sought to fight oppression. The army struck down anyone suspected of being in an opposition group with many being murdered and more simply vanishing with no trace. Indeed, the film's dedication is to Avila's mother who is one of those who disappeared. So it's easy to see why he would want to tell a story about a boy growing up in this environment. I mention the historical aspect that sets the scene for "Clandestine Childhood" because it helps to have a little context. If you know nothing of what occurred, the screenplay does not spell it out. While the political climate is certainly prevalent and quite significant throughout, the primary story thread is more intimate. In many ways, this is simply a standard coming-of-age story. And as we see things through the eyes of the twelve year old protagonist, much of the bigger picture is only glimpsed in small snippets.Our young hero is Juan. As the movie opens, a targeted act of violence forces Juan's parents to flee from their home. Under an elaborate escape mechanism, they exit the country and then return with new names and documents. Much of the movie is how Juan rebuilds his childhood under the assumed identity of Ernesto. He goes to school, he experiences young love, and he bonds with his uncle. The danger of discovery is always lurking, but Juan just strives to be a normal kid. Although wizened by circumstances, he clearly understands that this is not some great adventure. He is both tied to his parents' cause as it is a way of bonding with them and alienated by it as it prevents him from having a simple existence. The movie is filled with sweet moments (an unplanned birthday), melancholy ones (a romantic getaway that goes south), and violent ones. As the truth catches up with Juan's family, he'll no longer have the option of remaining a child.I liked the unorthodox approach of "Clandestine Childhood." As I mentioned, we see only as much of the danger and turmoil in Argentina as Juan is aware of. Therefore, when confronted with the grim realities, it is all the more powerful. Avila also employs an interesting visual device when the violence escalates. At its most harrowing moments, the film changes to a graphic novel type illustration that is quite unexpected but surprisingly effective. It really seemed to fit the tone of the piece. Among the performances, Teo Gutiérrez Moreno (Juan) handles a difficult role well. I also liked Natalia Oreiro, as the mother, whose combination of compassion and strength gives the movie much of its identity. Best of all, though, Ernesto Alterio steals every scene he's in as Uncle Beto. It's an incredibly satisfying performance, and one of the movie's most important. The DVD's Bonus Short Film is called "Veo Veo" and it is the precursor of and basis for the main film. At 29 minutes, it shares the same basic plot and themes. But there is more childlike wonder with a younger lead. That juxtaposition almost made me like the short film better than the main feature! Overall, though, "Clandestine Childhood" is a well executed coming-of-age story set in extraordinary times. KGHarris, 4/13.
summary: A Potent Argentinean Drama: A Well Executed Coming-Of-Age Story Set In Extraordinary Times

reviewText: Es una pelicula excelente que se trata de la doble vida de un chico de once que vive en la Argentina de 1979, un pais en que toda la gente encuentra la guerra sucia entre los Montoneros de la bandera blanca y azul, y los fascistas de la bandera blanca y azul con el sol.  El chico Juan (como Juan Peron) entra en la escuela llamandose de Ernesto (como Ernesto Guevara).  Luego tiene un cumpleanos inesperado y ama a una chica con exito, pero todo cae en lo desastroso debido a la guerra en que sus parientes estan envolvidos.  La violencia se presenta en forma de dibujos.  Vemos todo con los ojos de Juan/Ernesto, la locura de deber que esconderse detras de cajas de mani y chocolate, de querer refugiarse en el Brasil con la chica que no lo quiere, y todo lo demas de una vida doble, loca y por fin inhumana.
summary: la doble vida de un chico de once

reviewText: Let me state upfront that I am a big fan of the Film Movement library of indie and foreign films, so much so that earlier in 2012, I finally gave in and joined the "DVD of the Month" club. This film is the December, 2012 release of that and incidentally this film is also "Year 10, Film 12" of the club, meaning this film marks the 120th movie to be released by the Film Movement DVD of the Month club."Clandestine Childhood" (2012 release from Argentina; 110 min.) brings the story of an Argentinean family in exile in Cuby in the late 1970s, when the parents (who are members of the Monteneros guerrilla movement) decide to return to Argentina under assumed identities, so as to resume the underground fight agains the Argetine military Junta government. The parents bring along their 2 children, 11 yr. old Juan and a baby sister. Juan's new assumed name is Ernesto. Ernesto attends school as a 5th grader and he develops a crush on a class mate of his, a girl named Maria. Will Ernesto's crush on Maria be reciprocated by her? Will Ernesto's parents continue their 'subversive' ways against the military dictatorship? Will it all end well? To tell you more of the plot would ruin your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.Several comments: director Benjamin Avila based the story on his own memoirs of those years, and in the liner notes that come with the DVD, he stresses that "this is not a political film" but of course it really is, even though it is also a tender coming of age story. The Montoneros underground movement against the Argentine military dictatorship was ultmately not very successfull (and neither was the military dictatorship, which gave up power after 7 years in 1983). The coming of age story of 11 yr. old Juan/Erensto is brought beautifully and with just the right amount of melancholy without becoming too sentimental. I enjoyed this movie from start to finish. But wait! there is more! As usual, there is a bonus short film, and the fascinating thing is that it is director Avila's earlier 25 min. short film called "Veo Veo" (I See I See), which in turn was the basis for "Clandestine Childhood", even though "Veo Veo" is set a few years earlier and the Juan character is now an 8 yr. old boy. Do not miss it! In all, "Clandestine Childhood" is yet another winning and worthy addition to the ever-growing Film Movement library. Happy 10 years, Film Movement, and keep those great indie and foreign releases coming!
summary: Tender coming of age story with serious political undercurrents
